reasoning: The critique targets a key step in Section 3.2: that linear (resource-separable) unbounded views are fussy not just because they require vast scale, but because value-per-unit-resource is assumed fat-tailed so only very specific configurations capture most value. If that fat-tail/"needle" picture fails (e.g., broad near-optimal plateaus), then this particular argument for linear-view fussiness weakens substantially—though the overall "no easy eutopia" thesis has other independent supports (multiplicative fragility; other moral-view analyses; scale requirement itself), so centrality is moderate rather than decisive. The critique’s argumentative force is decent: it identifies an extrapolation gap and states what would be needed to justify the leap (complexity/search-theoretic argument or explicit modeling). However it does not directly rebut the paper’s additional intrinsic-value considerations (e.g., alleged fat-tailedness of experience intensity, or the ‘uncertainty implies expected fat tails’ move), so it only partially undercuts the attacked claim. Most statements are plausible and largely accurate, with minimal fluff, and it stays tightly on one issue.
title: Institution-driven fat tails don’t justify narrow value targets in advanced civilizations
